messageBody:
On Tue, Jun 10, 2008 at 10:07 AM, Kent Beck <kentb@...> wrote:
> This is what DevCreek (www.devcreek.com) does, and the results are often
> surprising. For example, we noticed that on Wednesdays the DevCreek team
> itself wrote a quarter of the tests it wrote on other days. Turns out they
> were spending most of the day preparing for the weekly status meeting.

So. Side topic, and favorite horse-floggee of mine: did the metric
do anything for us that simply knowing the team well wouldn't have
already done? I'm assuming, here, dangerous habit, that there was no
team-perceived process-weakness on Wednesdays prior to the metric. If
that's a valid assumption, dangerous habit admitted, then this would
seem to be a case where a metric -- not free -- gave us a false
positive -- not free -- requiring at least a little bit of
investigation to determine root cause -- not free. Metrics are
scarily complex to me, and I wish my world had either fewer of them,
or fewer people relying on them.

> Teams
> using DevCreek don't seem to change their behavior much on the basis of the
> feedback, though, which I find surprising. Perhaps the feedback isn't really
> all that useful, perhaps we don't have the right presentation of the
> information, or perhaps people just need to get used to the idea that the
> information is there for them.

Or, another favorite equine victim of mine, perhaps people are
decidedly less rational than we routinely realize.

Of course, once having typed this in, I immediately jump to another
way of seeing it: put scare quotes around 'rational'. To make this
second idea more clear, I'll say I might have theorized that the team
would respond (incorrectly) by 'rationally' honoring feedback that
didn't meet its -- what words to use here? -- gestalt self-image. In
fact, the team responded (correctly) by 'irrationally' ignoring
feedback that didn't meet that gestalt self-image.

A third way in to the puzzle: information is not useful until it is
integrated into a framework of meaning. At any given time, any such
framework has a loose boundary (the so-called hermeneutic horizon),
which represents the only possible locations where new information can
be fit. If the boundary is not situated where the new information can
be fit in, it will be ignored, hence useless. So it pays to focus
one's attention not just on generating data, but on generating the
data that will fit the current boundary for the current group and
enable that group to become what it wants.

This is why I am so negative about quests for ever-more-detailed
metrics, or one-size-fits-all approaches to measuring progress in
human enterprise. Down this road lies Taylor, and a reversion of some
particularly hard won 20th century knowledge. When someone posts
about "what metric is best?", I wish we could all post back "the one
that helps your team".

I'm reminded of a magnificent insight granted to me by Jerome Bruner,
who somewhere remarks that the purpose of therapy is not to reveal the
truth, but to construct a story which enables the patient to move
towards his or her goal.

Cheers,
Hill
